intro: Galium transcarpaticum, commonly known as Transcarpathian bedstraw, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes coffee and gardenias, and is characterized by its small, white or pale pink flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or forested areas and has slender, branched stems covered in fine hairs. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often have a slightly hairy surface, while its fruits are small, dry capsules that release seeds when mature. Galium transcarpaticum is often found in alpine and subalpine habitats, where it thrives in cool, moist environments.
